abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Structural Adjustment
            Loan Project in Algeria are as follows: overall outcome of
            the project was rated as marginally satisfactory, and the
            performance of the Bank and the Borrower were rated
            satisfactory. Some of the lessons learned from the project
            are: (a) an active and large scale employment creation
            strategy is necessary in a situation marked by very high
            unemployment to enable the political and social feasibility
            of a swift implementation of reforms; (b) sequencing of
            reforms matters. Trade and exchange rate liberalization
            should go hand-in-hand with privatization and support to the
            private sector for a quick supply response. The lack of such
            a balanced and mutually supportive approach contributes to
            de-industrialization, weakens the support for reform, and
            undermines the implementation of the very trade and exchange
            liberalization as they become unsustainable; and (c)
            unbalanced and prolonged emphasis on stabilization at the
            expense of structural reforms, and exaggerated valuation of
            improved short term macro performance indicators alone
            diverts attention from the need to accelerate structural
            reform, as it gives policymakers a false sense of having
            finished the agenda and gives the general population a false
            expectation of an end to its pain.

5082759.majtheme: Public sector governance,Financial and private sector development,Rule of law

abstracts.cdata!:
The Structural Adjustment Loan Project
            (SAL) is the central element of the Bank's assistance
            strategy for Algeria. This strategy aims to support the
            Algerian authorities in: 1) stimulating private-sector-led
            growth; 2) protecting the poor during the transition to a
            market-based economy; and 3) enhancing the country's
            ability to mobilize external resources. The SAL builds on
            progress made under the recent Economic Rehabilitation
            Support Loan, under which the Algerian authorities made
            tangible progress in adjustment and met many of the agreed
            objectives, including the adoption of a privatization law,
            sooner than anticipated. The loan supports an adjustment
            program that is moving Algeria closer to its goal of an
            open, market-based economy in the context of growth and
            increased employment. The key components of the project
            include: 1) macroeconomic stabilization and rationalization
            of public expenditures; 2) support for public enterprise
            reform and private sector development, including: (a)
            large-scale privatization of small public enterprises, where
            local demand exists; (b) further reforms designed to limit
            the losses of large public enterprises and ready for
            privatization; (c) increased private-sector participation in
            subcontracting and in the provision of municipal services;
            and (d) financial sector reform designed to increase
            competition and create needed new financial instruments; and
            3) support the already successful implemented new social
            protection system, including some measures to improve its performance.
